jessiejune14: Thank you for being a relentless advocate. It helps & is incredibly inspiring. 💕

nicolecostello_: AMEN 🤩 I love you, and your honesty. The type of person who calls depression laziness is the same person that would vote for Trump.
cdcwood: You're incredible ❤️hugs and love to you 😘
the_nicoliest_of_nicoles: You are such a light and relief to me! lipglossandbrassknuckles: Thank you @jengotch for stating what many of us ‘lazy’ individuals experience.
carlacoug: This so made me cry. I still have people that think I'm lazy or think my mom is lazy and as you know it can be one of the worst feelings in the world to have your "loved ones" not understand. Then it hurts even more when they don't even try to understand. Having someone project a stereotype on you that isn't true is so belittling. For whatever reason I really needed to read this right now. Thank you thank you thank you for sharing your journey and being an advocate for others!!!
jeweledspirit: I can feel this so much! I have both Depression and Fibromyalgia, and wow , so many people just do not get it. Thanks for sharing your experiences in such a relatable way!! So appreciated! Xo
komasabroughton: Thank you. You have a powerful voice and I appreciate you using it to free our minds from the depression and prejudice we experience.
jocelynmathewes: Thank you! I find that the laziness lable makes the depression worse. 😞
cpfry: thank you for posting this — i will admit, I fell into that trap with my fiancé. brantlea: Thank you for all your honesty about your struggles with depression and bipolar disorder. There’s so many people that suffer quietly, I’m sure you are making a difference.
rachael_amy: You are an absolute goddess and anyone who says otherwise can suck it.
kateaureliastudio: Thank you for sharing all you do about depression - mental illness is so misunderstood and yet so prevalent in so many’s lives. If only it were that easy... laziness would be so easy to cure!
sourcherrycouk: @jengotch I was having the same trouble as you with messages but I logged out and back in and it’s sorted its self out 💖
leftcoastmade: Thank you so much for sharing! ❤️
brooklynandwest: @jengotch Thank you for being an example and being so real. I, too, am “lazy” to some, yet managed to open & run my own boutique for years. And it’s not easy.
ashestofire: Moving ones ass instead of ones mouth benefits EVERYONE💡(common sense)
domino34: Thank you for talking about this Jen; it’s bloody hard to live in this hinterland, assuming everyone is brimming over with happiness and imagining your lot in life is to sit in the shadows 😔
sharikensley: Absolutely! Thank you! The more vocal we are, when we feel safe and comfortable to do so, the faster the thinking around this topic will change!

emmesscee: Living with depression is the opposite of lazy. The fact that you manage to survive and thrive through it is a testament to the battle that you fight every day. Thank you for these important words. ❤️

imsmartemis: Thanks for this post, and your stories. 👏🏽
ashley_stickler: Thank you! I have an alternate persona that was created when I was a teenager; Mama Lazzy... she's still around.
so.kayle: Thank you for being bold and inspiring always 💖
abbywakerley: Thank you. I really need this x
thegangstersdamour: 💛✨💖✨💛keep going on your beautiful path 🌟don't get distracted by other people. They are walking theirs. And by the sound of it, that person calling you lazy is probably having a very hard time being so hard on her/himself💞
kimberlymaeholmes: The fact that someone commented that to you makes me so sad! I suffer from “laziness” too and that’s just such an insensitive thing to say 😔 You’re an amazing human!! 😘💕
alonamarie: God, anyone who knows depression knows it’s the opposite of lazy. It is all consuming, eat you from the inside, exhausting 24/7 self hatred. It’s the busiest I’ve ever been, trapped in my own depressed head.
jessdotcee: I stopped going out towards the end of high school and all my friends would talk about me behind my back about how lazy I was and say that I would just spend all my time at home doing nothing, still to this day I have never gotten over that. shesfrommiami: This photo is amazing and so are you. From one "lazy" girl to another! 👊🏼🌸
mrs_jakeryan: Yes to this post! Fantastic picture (and such skinny ankles)!
cassandaston: Thanks for posting this. I think a lot of us who battle with depression are actually high functioning, crazy capable, bad ass go-getters, until we’re not. luckypennycreative: A fucking men, @jengotch. A fucking men.
shophydrokitty: I’m lazy and continually fighting depression as well. In the midst of it I️ went through a long divorce and started my business. juliefordherbison: Props for sharing your story. The person who posted that depression is the same as laziness is intellectually lazy. There is so much info out there about depression they should know better if the did the slightest bit of research.
frnt.paige: Yessss!! Every bit of this! As an entrepreneur it can be the hardest because it’s a toxic circle of being being depressed, being excited to be in charge of your own life and being pissed at yourself for. It taking charge “the way you should”. Thank you for sharing your version 💕💕
monicamarie5: So necessary to hear this today, thank you for sharing
acerbic_alice: And being criticised just feeds the beast!
jessicadaviesmetalworks: It took me years to finally get this. You are absolutely correct and realizing it has made me such a better pillar of strength and support to those I know and love who are deeply affected by depression. Sending love to you, Jen. ❤️
tirzahlouisa: Thank you for continually shedding light on this 💜
themirandarodgers: Depression isn’t laziness. It’s a debilitating sadness you can’t explain away or logically get over. What a turd of a person. Without medication I’d be in bed all day, no motivation, in the pits of despair. Laziness doesn’t enter the equation.
lloyd_noble: People that suffer with anxiety, depression or any other mental illness totally GET IT! I️ understand this on a million levels. It is literally impossible to try and explain to people how it feels or what it looks like or how sometimes you may feel “ok” and then other times you feel completely hopeless, lost, can’t focus, can’t sleep, can’t think, can’t breathe and can’t even “BE”. I’m sure for every person it’s an entirely different experience, but we all share your pain. I️ find it quite ironic though that even throughout history, most creative geniuses have suffered incredible “episodes” of depression, often times, being described as “MAD”. The comfort is knowing that the madness, as awful as it is, also allows for some of the most creative and artistic expression that other people do not possess. This creativity cannot be given, learned, or taught- it is an innate ability given to you! I’ve yet to meet a true creative artist that didn’t suffer from some varying level of depression/mental illness. Keep on keepin on! I️ get it, and others do as well. I️ see no need to apologize or explain it. If people don’t get it, or aren’t willing to understand it- they can keep it moving too! #bandtogetherfellowcreativenutbags 💕💕💕💕💕💕💕💕💕💕💕💕💕
jennrak: Thank you for being open and honest 🙏❤️.
stephjgilbert: Thank you. I too have been feeling “lazy” lately and I resonate so much with all of your stories today. When the things you were excited about feel too heavy out of nowhere, that’s not laziness— it’s chemical. You know you got this. 💪🏼💕 sending love!

inkiedinkie: ❤️❤️❤️ it’s so difficult bc even your mom or close fam call you lazy or see you as such. For you not to believe it and know it’s the disease when you are fighting such a monster it’s terrible.
itsthepickles: Oh I've been there. Certain times in my life called for lazy days on the couch and wine starting at noon. That numbness was debilitating! lovely_odyssey: A million thank you! Yesterday I saw someone post “choose happiness” and the first thing I thought was, it’s not that simple for everyone.
survival.bias: You’ve been an inspiration to me for years now. Thank you for your constant honesty and rawness.
chloe_kiser: Good reminder! But I know that when I’m feeling ‘lazy’ it can be impossible sometimes to realize what is really going on, even though I should be like, ‘duh’. It’s like I have depression and anxiety amnesia😬
kser369: I watched your story, i wish i could help. 🌷🦄🍄
instanjul: So damn true! Thank you Jen! ❤️🙏🏽
queen.of.crumbs: Duuuude. Thank you. It’s so real. Thank you for being honest and vulnerable.
lisa_lizana: Thank you for saying this. I feel tremendous guilt daily about all the things I should be doing, want to do, but can't seem to get done. The guilt just feeds into the depression and makes everything spiral. 😔
luckypennyblog: Thank you and love you for this 💗
riley.calls.me.mom: Sad that this needs to be explained, but so true. You can be the most hard-working, motivated person, and depression can hit you when you least expect it. I suffered from depression throughout my teens and twenties, and finally, when I hit my 30s I thought I was good. I had all the energy and motivation in the world and I was kicking add in my career (as a Behavior Analyst, go figure). Then, I had my daughter a year and a half ago, and I've been suffering from postpartum depression and anxiety and it's taking a toll on my work life and home life. But I'm pushing through. Taking one day at a time. Some days, I just want to sit around and do nothing, but I'm not LAZY. Anyway, thank you @jengotch for sharing this and your story over the years. It's wonderful to have someone so candid about the struggles of mental illness, especially when you are a successful, driven, hard working woman, as you are. 💕 btw, I love your brand. Perfect combo of cynicism, sarcasm, and bright colors to make this crazy girl happy.
andrea.fairservice: Bless you Jen. Depression is a recent “addition” to my life. Meaning, I’m just now able to identify what I’m feelings are symptoms (if that’s what they are called) of depression. A few weeks ago I spent an entire Saturday in my bed. I literally did not have the will to get up, eat, function; and once I snapped my self out of it I felt so terrible like I wasted one of my precious days off being a lazy dick in bed. Thank you for this, and everything you share. It’s truly helped me learn more about this and I’m thankful you’re so willing to share such personal, "hard for others to understand," issues. xo
ginarockenwagner: My old boss called me lazy! I said that's funny, the doctor called it Generalized Anxiety Disorder when he wrote my prescription. 🤔

automatism: 💕 Thank you so much for this, Jen!
ange_who33: Explaining mental illness to others who don’t suffer can be like talking to a wall. Having people like you and @imlauramiller to be such strong advocates makes people who suffer feel less alone. You da best.
debbedowner: Yes! I’m a scientist who studies depression, and it’s so important that people it’s a REAL disease, with real biological reasons for why it happens, just like cancer, heart disease, Alzheimer’s, etc.
_karawr: Thank you for talking about depression. 💕
jennrdart: Thank you for sharing. I suffer from major depression and have been feeling really bad lately especially when all I want to do is be in bed. zilahdrahn: i love you so much. strong woman
abubblylife: I love the TED talk on depression where he says- “the opposite of depression is not happiness, it’s vitality”. That life sucking feeling depression takes from us. 💕 #breakthestigma

joiebutter: 👏🏼👏🏼👏🏼 it’s so hard! i beat myself up and call myself lazy as some twisted form of “motivation” while i would never call anyone else suffering from depression lazy. thanks for the reminder.
